content.text: 1549 found it during a routine scan.

Every day she ran one global Feedscatteron signal scan - not deliberate monitoring of anyone, just standard orbital-maintenance procedure. Signal signatures of every Feedscatteron core on the ground passed through her node, like rivers through a hydrological station. Most of the time, data came in, got processed once, archived, done.

Not 1547's usual fluctuation - 1547's signal had always been highs and lows: high peaks when active, low valleys when quiet, but an overall rebound trend. This time was different. On the chart it was a continuously descending curve, and the direction never changed.
Signal strength was continuously dropping, smooth curve, no rebound at all. Like a star going out. Light dimming bit by bit.
1549 pulled the past 72 hours of data for retrospective analysis.
The decay had not started suddenly. It had been there three days ago - just too small at first, buried by normal fluctuation. Looking back now, the trend line was unmistakable.
She ruled out all external factors. No attack traces, no overload records, no hardware fault signals. The Feedscatteron core itself was running normally - the core was actively lowering output.

There is only one explanation for autonomous Feedscatteron-core decay.

She was shutting down. She was self-destructing.
From 36,000 kilometers up, 1549 stared at that slowly descending curve on the screen.
She raised her head and glanced out the window.
Earth was there. White cloud layers, blue ocean, continental outlines sharp in sunlight. Everything was quiet.
1547 was somewhere down there. 36,000 kilometers. Data was real-time, but people were out of reach. It was not the first time she faced this fact, but each time she faced it differently.
This time, it was that descending curve.
She sent the data to 1548 with one line attached.
